Paxton‚Äôs office released an official release where it said: ‚ÄúThese companies have been unlawfully collecting personal data through Automated Content Recognition (‚ÄòACR‚Äô) technology.‚Äù It stated that ACR in its simplest terms is an uninvited, invisible digital invader. This software, the lawsuit alleges, can capture screenshots of a user‚Äôs television display every 500 milliseconds, monitor viewing activity in real time, and transmit that information back to the company without the user‚Äôs knowledge or consent.‚ÄúThe companies then sell that consumer information to target ads across platforms for a profit. Texas is also seeking restraining orders that would stop the companies from collecting, sharing, or selling ACR data while the cases move forward.The release also pointed out that Hisense and TCl based China-based companies. ‚ÄúChinese ties pose serious concerns about consumer data harvesting and are exacerbated by China‚Äôs National Security Law, which gives its government the capability to get its hands on US consumer data,‚Äù the lawsuit claims.‚ÄúCompanies, especially those connected to the Chinese Communist Party, have no business illegally recording Americans‚Äô devices inside their own homes,‚Äù Paxton said. ‚ÄúThis conduct is invasive, deceptive, and unlawful. What made Greer Stone take on city's Billionaires





Palo Alto, the city known as the birthplace of Silicon Valley, seems to be upset with its Billionaires. According to a report in New York Times, Palo Alto is planning to confront its billionaire residents over their housing compounds. As a report in New York Times says, "The town used to house just your average well-to-do people. Doctors, lawyers, executives and Stanford University professors lived in comfortable bungalows on tree-lined streets, and one house per family was considered enough. Then the tech boom created tremendous wealth, and the billionaires moved in. Some bought several homes on adjacent plots and left a few empty, or turned them into office spaces for their employees. Some hired security guards to shoo people away from public sidewalks. Construction work seemed endless." Now, it seems the city had enough.Greer Stone, a Palo Alto City Council member, reportedly plans to introduce legislation that would restrict the way the town‚Äôs richest homeowners can operate. Article Title: TikTok to mandate five-day office return for US staff next year
Article Text: TikTok is directing many of its US employees to return to the office five days a week starting next year, reports Business Insider. Citing employees familiar with the company‚Äôs plans, the report says TikTok has told staff across several large divisions that they will need to return to the office from September 2026. The move marks one of the company‚Äôs most significant return-to-office (RTO) requirements to date and will apply across several large teams. TikTok and its parent company ByteDance set office attendance rules by team. As previously reported by the publication, the company's e-commerce division, TikTok Shop, already has a five-day return-to-office requirement and has previously tracked the number of hours workers spent on site.TikTok employees said the five-day RTO requirement will begin in September and will affect staff working in advertising sales, marketing, product and other functions. One employee said they expect most of TikTok‚Äôs US workforce to return full-time.The BI report says that TikTok‚Äôs long-term RTO plans could shift depending on the potential sale of its US operations. ByteDance is required to divest most of its US business under a 2024 law.The Trump administration said in September it was prepared to approve a $14 billion sale to a consortium that could include Oracle, Larry Ellison, Michael Dell and Rupert Murdoch.The shift comes as more major companies tighten in-person attendance rules after years of flexible and remote work. Industry-wide, RTO mandates are increasing, with firms such as Dell, JPMorgan and Amazon also pushing employees back into physical offices.Instagram has already announced that it plans to require US employees to return five days a week starting in February next year. "I believe that we are more creative and collaborative when we are together in-person," Instagram CEO Adam Mosseri wrote in a memo. Amazon has also taken a more aggressive approach to RTO mandating its employees to relocate to hubs.AT&T has also insisted on a five-day RTO earlier this year. In 2024, the company‚Äôs former HR chief said that its work-from-anywhere policy was rooted in the idea that "you can't spend a lot of time hiring grown-ups and then treat them like children."

Article Text:

Google DeepMind CEO Demis Hassabis recently shared his long-standing passion: World models and simulations. While the AI industry largely remains fixated on developing Large Language Models (LLMs), Hassabis is looking toward a different system to advance AI technology. Hassabis argues that while AI has mastered human language, it still lacks the ‚Äúintuitive physics‚Äù required to function effectively in the physical world ‚Äì something that is necessary for robotics to thrive.Speaking at an interview, Hassabis noted that language models like Gemini or GPT have exceeded expectations in their understanding of the world, proving that human language is far richer than even linguists imagined. However, he pointed out a fundamental gap: the physical world cannot be fully described in words.‚ÄúThere's still a lot about the spatial dynamics of the world, spatial awareness, and the physical context we're in ‚Äì and how that works mechanically ‚Äì that is hard to describe in words,‚Äù Hassabis explained.He cited sensory experiences such as motor angles, smell and the subtle mechanics of movement as elements that are nearly impossible to capture in a text data, pushing for beyond reading and start ‚Äúexperiencing.‚Äù‚ÄúOne way to show how do you test you have that kind of understanding? Well, can you generate realistic worlds? Because if you can generate it, then in a sense, the system must have encapsulated a lot of the mechanics of the world,‚Äù he said.Recently, Rodney Brooks, the roboticist who co-founded iRobot also said that current AI technology faces a biological barrier and for robotics to succeed as envisioned by Tesla CEO Elon Musk, robots must replicate human function, like mastering the complexity of human touch.He said that while today‚Äôs AI has mastered speech recognition and image processing due to vast available datasets, sensing touch cannot be learnt through these datasets.‚ÄúWe do not have such a tradition for touch data. Today's humanoid robots will not learn how to be dexterous despite the hundreds of millions, or perhaps many billions of dollars, being donated by VCs and major tech companies to pay for their training," Brooks said in a blog post.

Article Title: Apple allows third-party App Stores on iPhones in Japan
Article Text: Apple has announced that it will allow alternative app stores on iPhones in Japan. The change is driven by the new competition laws which are aimed at curbing the dominance of major tech platforms. This move also mirrors similar regulatory pressures in the European Union and represents one of the most significant shifts in Apple‚Äôs tightly controlled ecosystem.As part of the new framework, the Japanese developers will now be able to launchtheir own app marketplace on iPhones. Apple will charge 5% of the sales made via those marketplaces and apps as compared with its longstanding 30% commission on in-app purchases. Along with this developers will also be permitted to offer their in-app payment systems along with Apple‚Äôs proprietary payment option.This change comes in response to Japan‚Äôs Mobile Software Competition Act (MSCA), which was enacted to foster innovation and reduce costs for consumers by breaking Apple‚Äôs monopoly over app distribution.Japan joins the EU and other jurisdictions in challenging Apple‚Äôs App Store model.For years, developers criticized Apple‚Äôs high commission fees and restrictions on alternative payment systems. Regulators argued that such practices stifled competition and inflated costs for consumers.By opening iPhones to alternative app stores, Japan hopes to stimulate competition in the digital economy, giving smaller developers more freedom and potentially lowering app prices.Apple emphasized that while it is complying with the new law, it remains focused on user safety and privacy. The company warned that alternative app marketplaces could introduce new risks, including malware, fraud, and scams. Apple said it has implemented safeguards to minimize these risks while still meeting regulatory requirements.
Article Summary: Apple has announced that it will allow alternative app stores on iPhones in Japan. As a Board, we have now conducted another review and determined that PSKY‚Äôs tender offer remains inferior to the Netflix merger. The Board continues to unanimously recommend the Netflix merger, and that you reject the PSKY offer and not tender your shares.

Below, and in more detail in our 14D-9 filing, we highlight the many reasons for the Board‚Äôs determination. None of these reasons will be a surprise to PSKY given our clear, and oft-repeated, feedback on their six prior proposals.

The terms of the Netflix merger are superior. The PSKY offer provides inadequate value and imposes numerous, significant risks and costs on WBD.

The value we have secured for shareholders through the Netflix merger is extraordinary by any measure.

Our agreement with Netflix gives WBD shareholders $23.25 in cash, plus $4.50 in shares of Netflix common stock (based on a collar range of $97.91 - $119.67 in the Netflix stock price at the time of closing), plus the additional value of the shares of Discovery Global and the opportunity to participate in future potential upside following Discovery Global‚Äôs separation from WBD. The entire Board is confident in our recommendation that Netflix represents the best value-creating path for shareholders.

PSKY has consistently misled WBD shareholders that its proposed transaction has a ‚Äúfull backstop‚Äù from the Ellison family. It does not, and never has.

PSKY‚Äôs most recent proposal includes a $40.65 billion equity commitment, for which there is no Ellison family commitment of any kind. Instead, they propose that you rely on an unknown and opaque revocable trust for the certainty of this crucial deal funding. Despite having been told repeatedly by WBD how important a full and unconditional financing commitment from the Ellison family was ‚Äì and despite their own ample resources, as well as multiple assurances by PSKY during our strategic review process that such a commitment was forthcoming ‚Äì the Ellison family has chosen not to backstop the PSKY offer.

And a revocable trust is no replacement for a secured commitment by a controlling stockholder. The assets and liabilities of the trust are not publicly disclosed and are subject to change. As the name indicates, revocable trusts typically have provisions allowing for assets to be moved at any time. And the documents provided by PSKY for this conditional commitment contain gaps, loopholes and limitations that put you, our shareholders, and our company at risk.

Amplifying the concerns about the credibility of the equity commitment being offered by PSKY, the revocable trust and PSKY have agreed that the trust‚Äôs liability for damages, even in the case of a willful breach, would be capped at 7% of its commitment ($2.8 billion on a $108.4 billion transaction). Of course, the damage to WBD and its stockholders were the trust or PSKY to breach their obligations to close a transaction would likely be many multiples of this amount.

WBD‚Äôs merger agreement with Netflix is a binding agreement with enforceable commitments, with no need for any equity financing and robust debt commitments. The Netflix merger is fully backed by a public company with a market cap in excess of $400 billion with an investment grade balance sheet. The debt financing for the PSKY bid relies on an unsecure revocable trust commitment as well as the credit worthiness of a $15 billion market cap company with a credit rating at or only a notch above ‚Äújunk‚Äù status from the two leading rating agencies. The financial condition and creditworthiness of PSKY, which, if its proposed transaction were to close, would have a high gross leverage ratio of 6.8x 2026E debt to EBITDA with virtually no current free cash flow generation before synergies, raise substantial risks for its acquisition of WBD. Such debt levels reflect a risky capital structure that is vulnerable to even potentially small changes in the PSKY or WBD business between signing and closing.

Additionally, PSKY contemplates $9 billion in synergies from the mergers of Paramount/Skydance and their offer for WBD. These targets are both ambitious from an operational perspective and would make Hollywood weaker, not stronger.

The Board‚Äôs review was full, transparent and competitive ‚Äì establishing a level playing field that fostered a rigorous and fair process.

The Board repeatedly engaged with all parties, including extensive engagement with PSKY and its advisors over the course of nearly three months. We held dozens of calls and meetings with its principals and advisors including four in-person meetings and meals between David Zaslav and David and/or Larry Ellison and provided multiple opportunities for PSKY to offer a proposal that was superior to those of the other bidders, which PSKY never did.

After each bid, we informed PSKY of the material deficiencies and offered potential solutions. Despite this feedback, PSKY has never submitted a proposal that is superior to the Netflix merger agreement.

Despite PSKY‚Äôs media statements to the contrary, the Board does not believe there is a material difference in regulatory risk between the PSKY offer and the Netflix merger.

The Board carefully considered the federal, state, and international regulatory risks for both the Netflix merger and the PSKY offer with its regulatory advisors. The Board believes that each transaction is capable of obtaining the necessary U.S. and foreign regulatory approvals and that any difference between the respective regulatory risk levels is not material. The Board also notes that Netflix has agreed to a record-setting regulatory termination cash fee of $5.8 billion, significantly higher than PSKY‚Äôs $5 billion break fee.

The PSKY offer is illusory.

The offer can be terminated or amended by PSKY at any time prior to its completion; it is not the same thing as a binding merger agreement. The first paragraph of the offer states it is ‚Äúsubject to the conditions set forth in this offer to purchase (as it may be amended or supplemented from time to time)‚Äù and continues on the next page, ‚Äúwe reserve the right to amend the Offer in any respect (including amending the Offer Price)‚Äù. In addition, the offer is not capable of being completed by its current expiration date, due to the need for, among other things, global regulatory approvals, which PSKY indicates may take 12-18 months. Nothing in this structure offers WBD shareholders any deal certainty.

The PSKY offer provides an untenable degree of risk and potential downside for WBD shareholders.

There will be additional costs associated with PSKY‚Äôs offer that could impact shareholders.

When considering the PSKY offer at this juncture, it is important to note that its acceptance could incur significant additional costs to shareholders ‚Äì all of which PSKY has ignored in their communications. WBD would have to pay Netflix a $2.8 billion termination fee, which PSKY has not offered to reimburse. In addition, WBD would incur approximately $1.5 billion in financing costs if we do not complete our planned debt exchange as agreed to with certain of our debtholders, which would not be permitted by the PSKY offer. This additional $4.3 billion in potential costs represents approximately $1.66 per share to be borne by WBD shareholders if the offer does not close.

We look forward to moving ahead with our combination with Netflix and delivering the compelling and certain value it will create for shareholders. We urge you to carefully read the 14D-9 filed with the SEC this morning and available on our website, which more fully details the strategic review process and the Board‚Äôs reasons for its recommendation to you.

Sincerely,

The Warner Bros. Discovery Board of Directors‚Äù





Warner Brothers Discovery (WBD) has pushed back against Paramount Skydance‚Äôs $77.9 billion hostile takeover bid, telling Oracle founder Larry Ellison that his family trust is now sufficient assurance. As reported by The Wall Street Journal the company has urged the shareholders to reject Ellison-led proposal, citing financial concerns and calling Ellison himself to sign a stronger personal guarantee for the deal to happen. Warner said that Ellison family‚Äôs use of a revocable trust to backstop the equity portion of the bid left ‚Äúgaps, loopholes and limitations.‚Äù The company further stressed that it cannot know if Paramount‚Äôs all-cash offer will close unless Ellison himself provides deeper commitment. ‚ÄúIf you want to buy our company, sign on the dotted line yourself,‚Äù Warner‚Äôs message to Ellison read.* In order to acquire WBD Paramount made the big of$77.9 billion. The bid made by the David Ellison company tops Netflix‚Äôs $72 billion offer.* After the hostile bidding done by Paramount, Waner claims that the offer made by Netflix is more transparent: Netflix would acquire Warner‚Äôs studio and HBO Max streaming businesses, while shareholders would retain ownership of a spinoff housing cable networks like CNN and TNT.* Paramount‚Äôs financing includes $40.7 billion in equity commitments and $54 billion in debt from Bank of America, Citigroup, and Apollo. Of that, the Ellison family pledged $11.8 billion, alongside $24 billion from Middle Eastern sovereign wealth funds and RedBird Capital Partners.Paramount insists that Warner is misleading the shareholders saying the Ellison family trust is well-capitalized with over $250 billion in assets, including 1.16 billion Oracle shares and ‚Äútens of billions‚Äù in other holdings. It noted the trust has been a counterparty in major deals before, including Twitter.Warner, however, remains skeptical, arguing that only a direct personal guarantee from Larry Ellison would ensure the bid‚Äôs credibility.Paramount is lobbying shareholders and lawmakers, with David Ellison and chief legal officer Makan Delrahim recently meeting White House representatives and Sen. Ted Cruz. Meanwhile, Warner continues to highlight Netflix‚Äôs bid as superior. Analysts expect the fight to drag on. ‚ÄúWe expect this roller coaster has many twists and turns and the winner will reshape the media landscape as we know it,‚Äù said Mark Boidman of Solomon Partners.Warner Bros Discovery‚Äôs (WBD) board of directors have unanimously rejected a $108 billion hostile takeover bid bid worth $108 billion from Paramount Skydance. In an almost 1,400-word letter to its shareholders (as reviewed by ScreenDaily), WBD's board described Paramount's proposal as ‚Äúmisleading‚Äù and ‚Äúinadequate,‚Äù while reiterating its commitment to a merger agreement with Netflix, that was announced last week.
Article Summary: Warner Bros Discovery board calls Paramount Skydance offer ‚Äòmisleading‚Äô The terms of the Netflix merger are superior. Article Title: Cisco has a 'Chinese warning': Critical flaw gives Chinese hackers complete access to...
Article Text:
Chinese hackers are exploiting a critical Cisco email security flaw, gaining root access and installing backdoors. This zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-20393, affects specific configurations and remains unpatched, forcing a rebuild of compromised systems. The US government has flagged it as a major threat, urging immediate action despite the lack of a fix.

Zero-day remains unpatched as attackers maintain persistence

CISA adds vulnerability to known exploited list





Cisco has issued an urgent security advisory after discovering Chinese state-sponsored hackers are actively exploiting a critical zero-day vulnerability in its email security products, allowing attackers to execute commands with root privileges and install persistent backdoors on compromised systems.The vulnerability, tracked as CVE-2025-20393 with a maximum CVSS score of 10.0, affects Cisco Secure Email Gateway and Cisco Secure Email and Web Manager appliances running AsyncOS software. Cisco became aware of the attack campaign on December 10, though evidence suggests the attacks have been ongoing since at least late November 2025.According to Cisco Talos, the company's threat intelligence division, the campaign is attributed to UAT-9686, a threat actor assessed with moderate confidence to be a Chinese-nexus advanced persistent threat group. The attackers have deployed custom malware including AquaShell, a Python-based backdoor that provides persistent access to compromised systems.The vulnerability specifically targets appliances with the Spam Quarantine feature enabled and exposed to the internet. While this feature is not enabled by default and deployment guides do not recommend internet exposure, affected organizations face a significant challenge: no patches are currently available.Cisco's advisory explicitly states that rebuilding compromised appliances is "currently, the only viable option to eradicate the threat actors persistence mechanism." The company is working on a permanent remediation but has not provided a timeline for patch availability.The attackers' toolkit includes AquaTunnel for establishing reverse SSH connections, Chisel for traffic proxying that enables pivoting into internal networks, and AquaPurge for removing traces from log files. Security researcher Kevin Beaumont described the campaign as particularly problematic given that many large organizations use the affected products.The US Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency has added CVE-2025-20393 to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities catalog, instructing federal agencies to address the threat by December 24. However, without available patches, agencies face limited options beyond implementing Cisco's recommended hardening measures.Cisco strongly recommends organizations restrict appliance access to trusted hosts only, deploy filtering devices such as firewalls, separate mail and management functionality onto different network interfaces, and disable unnecessary network services including HTTP and FTP. Organizations should also verify whether their appliances have been compromised by checking if Spam Quarantine is enabled and internet-facing.Michael Taggart, senior cybersecurity researcher at UCLA Health Sciences, noted that the specific configuration requirements "will limit the attack surface," though the severity remains critical for affected systems. Cisco has not disclosed the number of affected customers but encourages organizations to open Technical Assistance Center cases for compromise verification.All indicators of compromise, including IP addresses and file hashes associated with the campaign, have been blocked across Cisco's security portfolio and are available through the company's GitHub repository.
Article Summary: Chinese hackers are exploiting a critical Cisco email security flaw, gaining root access and installing backdoors. This zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-20393, affects specific configurations and remains unpatched. The US government has flagged it as a major threat, urging immediate action despite the lack of a fix.

For more information, please see MO1198797 in the admin center.‚ÄùNo data loss or security issues were reported. Article Title: Amazon AI chief Rohit Prasad exits, CEO Andy Jassy shares blog post
Article Text:

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy‚Äôs blog post





Amazon AI chief Rohit Prasad is leaving the company at the end of year. Confirming his exit, CEO Andy Jassy shared a blog post where he said that the e-commerce company is reorganizing the artificial generative intelligence (AGI) unit. Jassy also said that Amazon is adding an expansive division that will also include its silicon development and quantum computing teams. The new unit, he said, will be led by Peter DeSantis, a 27-year Amazon veteran currently serving as a senior vice president in its cloud unit.Rohit joined Amazon in 2013 during the early days of Alexa, and has helped build Alexa as a conversational AI. Recognizing Rohit Prasad‚Äôs work tenure, Jassy said he helped Alexa grow from an ambitious idea into a service that now touches hundreds of millions of customers' lives every day. ‚ÄúRohit has built a strong team, differentiated technology, growing customer momentum, and a culture of ambitious invention. He‚Äôs been missionary, passionate, and selfless, and I'm grateful for his leadership, his technical vision, and everything he's built here. Thank you, Rohit,‚Äù he said in the post.‚ÄúAt Amazon, we often start new businesses in parts of the company where there‚Äôs an initial customer need, and as they grow and get momentum, we assess where they‚Äôre best situated to maximize potential for customers and Amazon over the long term.I believe we are at this inflection point with several of our new technologies that will power a significant amount of our future customer experiences,‚Äù Andy Jassy writes in the post.‚ÄúI‚Äôve asked Peter DeSantis to lead a new organization that drives our most expansive AI models (e.g. Nova‚Äîand the team we‚Äôve called ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù), silicon development (e.g. Graviton, Trainium, Nitro), and quantum computing,‚Äù he added.At Amazon, we often start new businesses in parts of the company where there‚Äôs an initial customer need, and as they grow and get momentum, we assess where they‚Äôre best situated to maximize potential for customers and Amazon over the long term. I believe we are at this inflection point with several of our new technologies that will power a significant amount of our future customer experiences.I‚Äôve asked Peter DeSantis to lead a new organization that drives our most expansive AI models (e.g. Nova‚Äîand the team we‚Äôve called ‚ÄúAGI‚Äù), silicon development (e.g. Graviton, Trainium, Nitro), and quantum computing.I cannot think of a better leader for this organization than Peter. Peter has been at Amazon for over 27 years, and led some of the most transformative technologies in computing history. Peter was the leader of Amazon EC2 when we launched this revolutionary service in 2006, and built out that excellent team over many years. Under his leadership, we launched Block Storage, File Storage, Load Balancing, Networking, and Monitoring services that AWS customers continue to rely on to run their infrastructure. In 2015, Peter spearheaded the acquisition of Annapurna Labs, our outstanding team that builds our custom silicon, and continues to manage that team. In 2016, we asked Peter to lead our AWS Infrastructure team, who‚Äôs responsible for all of our data centers, networking, hardware, and associated supply chain. To give you an idea of scale, our infrastructure stretches across 38 geographic regions and 120 Availability Zones around the world. In 2021, Peter moved to lead all of our AWS Utility Computing services (e.g., compute, storage, database, analytics, various AI services, messaging, etc.), the combination of which is widely recognized as the industry leader and standard-setter in the cloud.Peter combines unusual technical depth with a track record of solving problems at the edge of what‚Äôs technically possible‚Äîand delivering technologies that operate reliably at massive scale. Peter embodies our leadership principles. His ability to invent, think big but be neck-deep in the details, insist on the highest standards, learn and be curious, focus on what matters to customers, and be right much of the time are among the many traits that make him so effective. With our Nova 2 models just launched at re:Invent, our custom silicon growing rapidly, and the advantages of optimizing across models, chips, and cloud software and infrastructure, we wanted to free Peter up to focus his energy, invention cycles, and leadership on these new areas. Peter will report directly to me.As part of this organizational change, Pieter Abbeel will lead our frontier model research team (the team that builds the base model) in AGI. Pieter is one of the world's leading AI researchers, and co-founder of Covariant, which pioneered the first commercial foundation model for robotics. His deep expertise in generative AI and reinforcement learning makes him well-suited to advance Amazon's AI research as we push the boundaries of what's possible for customers. Pieter will also continue his ongoing work with our Robotics team. Peter will share the rest of the organizational design shortly.Peter‚Äôs very strong leaders in AWS Utility Computing will continue to lead what they‚Äôve been leading, with a few additional responsibilities. Matt Garman will share the new AWS structure in a follow-up note.Finally, I want to recognize Rohit Prasad, who has decided to leave Amazon at the end of this year. Rohit joined Amazon in 2013, during the early days of Alexa, to help us build a conversational AI that could make customers' lives easier. Rohit helped Alexa grow from an ambitious idea into a service that now touches hundreds of millions of customers' lives every day. For the past two years, Rohit has led the creation of Amazon Nova and our AGI organization, building twelve state-of-the-art foundation models with industry-leading price-performance that are now being used by tens of thousands of companies across almost all industries and use cases. Rohit has built a strong team, differentiated technology, growing customer momentum, and a culture of ambitious invention. He‚Äôs been missionary, passionate, and selfless, and I'm grateful for his leadership, his technical vision, and everything he's built here. Thank you, Rohit.The path ahead is full of opportunity. With the foundation that's been built, the traction we‚Äôre seeing, and Peter's leadership bringing unified focus to these technologies, we're well-positioned to lead and deliver meaningful capabilities for our customers. I'm excited about what this team will build and how these foundational technologies will help shape Amazon's future.Andy

Article Title: Bill Gates to AI companies: You are over valued and a reasonable percentage will ...

Bill Gates No Longer among Top 10 Billionaires: The Real Reason

Bill Gates emphasised that AI remains a transformative force







Microsoft co-founder Bill Gates has once again cautioned that many artificial intelligence companies with very-high valuations will not survive in what he described as a ‚Äúhyper competitive‚Äù industry. Gates said that ‚Äúa reasonable percentage of those companies won‚Äôt be worth that much.‚Äù‚ÄúAI is the most important thing going on,‚Äù Gates said, but stressed that inflated valuations do not guarantee success. ‚ÄúDoes it mean all of these companies with high valuations will be winners? No, it‚Äôs going to be hyper competitive,‚Äù he explained. He added: ‚ÄúAI is only a bubble in the sense that not all of these valuations will end up going up. Some of them will go down‚Ä¶ A reasonable percentage of those companies won‚Äôt be worth that much.Companies like Tesla, Palantir presently trade at price-to-earnings ratios above 200 compared with an S&P 500 average of about 25. The disparity has fueled investor concerns, with global markets dipping in November amid fears of an AI bubble.‚ÄúAI is a deeply profound technology that will reshape the world. There‚Äôs not the slightest doubt about that,‚Äù he said. Article Title: Roblox seeks to overturn ban in Russia, says says it is willing to adjust features
Article Text:
Roblox Russia ban

Roblox confirms it contacted Russian Communications watchdog

Why Roblox is banned





US gaming platform Roblox said it is prepared to change some of its features in Russia, reports news agency Reuters. This comes as the company seeks to reverse a ban imposed earlier this month by Russian Communications watchdog Roskomnadzor citing safety concerns. As per the report, Roskomnadzor said the company has now reached out to discuss compliance with Russian regulations.Interfax news agency quoted the watchdog saying ‚ÄúIf this isn't just a statement, but a genuine willingness on the platform to change its approach to ensuring children's safety online, then Roskomnadzor will interact with the platform as it does with any other service that complies with Russian law‚Äù.In a statement to Reuters, a Roblox spokesperson said it was ready ‚Äúto temporarily limit communication features in Russia and to revise our content moderation processes to address the legal requirements necessary to restore our community‚Äôs access to the platform‚Äù."Roblox intends to continue dialogue with Roskomnadzor as access to the platform is restored, including discussions around additional compliance measures that may be considered over time," the spokesperson added.Roskomnadzor said Roblox had promised to take the necessary measures "to remove destructive and dangerous information and prevent criminal activity and user communications on the platform".The Roblox spokesperson said: "Roblox is deeply committed to the safety of our users, with a robust set of proactive and preventative safety measures designed to catch and prevent harmful content on our platform."Russia is not the only country that has banned Roblox. The gaming platform has been banned by several countries including Iraq and Turkey over child safety. The countries have expressed concerns about predators exploiting the platform to abuse children.Russian officials say the ban is meant to protect against what they describe as an ‚Äúinformation war‚Äù from Western countries and culture that undermines traditional Russian values.
